# Cambridge IGCSE™

CANDIDATE NAME

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 211, 905, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 178, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|>
0625/43  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 299, 317]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Theory (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[777, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|>
May/June 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 574]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 603, 220, 618]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 619, 730, 651]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A scientist fills a container with sea water. The container has dimensions \(30 \text{cm} \times 30 \text{cm} \times 40 \text{cm}\). The density of sea water is \(1020 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 144, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 591, 136]]<|/det|>
Calculate the mass of the sea water in the container.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 228, 920, 247]]<|/det|>
<form>mass = .................................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 260, 146, 279]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 260, 767, 279]]<|/det|>
Fig. 2.1 shows a submarine. The submarine is fully submerged in the sea.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 286, 761, 403]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 416, 532, 435]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 181, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 448, 920, 482]]<|/det|>
The atmospheric pressure is \(100 \text{kPa}\) and the total pressure on the top surface of the submarine is \(500 \text{kPa}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 494, 892, 513]]<|/det|>
Calculate the depth of the top surface of the submarine below the surface of the sea.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[517, 603, 920, 622]]<|/det|>
<form>depth = ......................................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 635, 181, 653]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 635, 905, 653]]<|/det|>
A hatch (an opening door) on the top surface of the submarine has an area of \(0.62 \text{m}^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 664, 920, 699]]<|/det|>
Calculate the downward force on the hatch due to the total pressure on the top surface of the submarine.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 775, 920, 794]]<|/det|>
<form>force = ......................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 807, 920, 825]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 816, 89]]<|/det|>
In a double-decker bus there are two passenger compartments, one above the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 146, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 615, 120]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 shows a double-decker bus on a tilted platform.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 128, 725, 312]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 325, 532, 344]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 357, 573, 375]]<|/det|>
The platform is used to test the stability of the bus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 388, 920, 421]]<|/det|>
The angle the bus makes with the horizontal is gradually increased until the bus begins to topple to the left.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 434, 465, 453]]<|/det|>
Explain why the bus begins to topple.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 526, 920, 545]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 558, 146, 576]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 558, 920, 591]]<|/det|>
There are 30 passengers in the upper compartment of the bus and 2 passengers in the bottom compartment of the bus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 604, 714, 622]]<|/det|>
State how this affects the stability of the bus and the reason for this.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 696, 920, 714]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
A bus is travelling along a straight road. The bus and the driver have a combined mass of \(16 000 \text{kg}\) when there are no passengers in it. The bus has 73 passengers. The average mass of each of the passengers is \(65 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 181, 151]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 133, 767, 151]]<|/det|>
Calculate the total mass of the bus, the driver and the 73 passengers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[519, 319, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
<form>mass = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 350, 181, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 350, 920, 383]]<|/det|>
The fully loaded bus accelerates uniformly from rest to a speed of \(14 \text{m/s}\). The time taken to reach a speed of \(14 \text{m/s}\) is \(20 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 396, 717, 414]]<|/det|>
Calculate the resultant force on the bus during the acceleration.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[522, 513, 920, 531]]<|/det|>
<form>force = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 902, 91]]<|/det|>

The power of the heater is \(50\mathrm{W.}\) The mass of the sand in the cup is \(550\mathrm{g.}\) The initial temperature of the sand is \(20^{\circ}\mathrm{C.}\) The heater is switched on for 2.0 minutes. The temperature is recorded until the temperature stops increasing. The highest temperature recorded by the thermometer is \(33^{\circ}\mathrm{C.}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 355, 181, 373]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 680, 920, 698]]<|/det|>
<form>specific heat capacity = ................................................ [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 710, 181, 728]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 860, 89]]<|/det|>
A radioactive nucleus of carbon decays to a nucleus of nitrogen by emitting a particle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 695, 120]]<|/det|>
Complete the nuclide equation and state the name of the particle.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 133, 630, 163]]<|/det|>
\[^{14}_{6}\mathrm {C}\longrightarrow ^{14}_{7}\mathrm {N}+\cdots \mathrm {X}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 186, 640, 203]]<|/det|>
name of particle X ................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 186, 920, 203]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 216, 146, 234]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 216, 920, 250]]<|/det|>
A radiation detector in a laboratory records a reading of 10 counts/min. There are no radioactive samples in the laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 263, 181, 282]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 387, 920, 420]]<|/det|>
Carbon-14 has a half-life of 5700 years. There are atoms of carbon-14 in all living organisms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 434, 920, 497]]<|/det|>
An archaeologist digs up some ancient wood. In the same laboratory as in **(b)(i)**, a sample of this ancient wood gives a reading of 20 counts/min. An equivalent sample of living wood gives a reading of 80 counts/min. It is suggested that the age of the ancient sample is 11400 years.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 510, 688, 528]]<|/det|>
